Innocent? No. Cyber Espionage and Hacking Cyber Attacks: China has been linked to a variety of cyber espionage campaigns targeting U.S. companies to steal intellectual property (IP). These attacks often aim at sensitive technological data, trade secrets, and proprietary designs. Chinese hacker groups, such as APT10 (also known as the "Stone Panda" group), have been accused of targeting U.S. companies in sectors like aerospace, healthcare, and technology. Notable Incidents: In 2020, the U.S. Justice Department indicted members of the Chinese hacking group APT41 for stealing intellectual property from U.S. companies and governments. In 2017, Chinese hackers were accused of infiltrating the systems of major U.S. tech firms like Equifax and others, leading to data breaches that compromised millions of records. The 2015 hack of the U.S. Office of Personnel Management (OPM) is often attributed to Chinese state-sponsored actors, though this breach was focused on government employee data, its techniques have been associated with IP theft strategies. Source: FBI Cyber Threat Overview 2. Industrial Espionage and State-Sponsored Efforts Chinese State-Sponsored Espionage: The Chinese government has been accused of facilitating espionage operations through state-backed programs such as the "Thousand Talents Program" (which encourages scientists and engineers to share intellectual property with China), and state-sponsored industrial espionage units. The â€œMade in China 2025â€ Plan: This Chinese economic initiative aims to make China a leader in high-tech industries, such as robotics, aerospace, and artificial intelligence (AI). Some of the strategies to achieve this have included aggressively acquiring U.S. technologies and intellectual property. U.S. Reports and Legal Actions: The U.S. Department of Justice and other agencies have been increasingly cracking down on Chinese industrial espionage activities. The U.S. has brought several cases against Chinese nationals accused of stealing U.S. technology for the benefit of Chinese state-owned enterprises (SOEs). In 2019, a Chinese national was arrested for attempting to steal agricultural biotech secrets from Monsanto.
